title: When you turn a light on, does the light instantly travel at the speed of light (186,000 miles a second), or does it start at 0 and increase its speed until it reaches its top speed? - Quora

response.answer_text: A light bulb emits spontaneous radiation. A laser emits stimulated emission thus the acronym Light Amplification Stimulated by Emission of Radiation. Both a light bulb and a laser can emit light in a visible range but the process by which they do so are quite different. Believe it or not, the reason a light bulb works is in, it’s own right, almost as complicated a process as a laser. There are several types, yet for our examples let’s go with the good old fashioned incandescent light bulb. The reason an incandescent light bulb is so bright is because the filament in which electrical current passes through burn incredibly hot. It must also remain in a vacuum or inert gas to prevent the filament from oxidizing lest the material chemically react causing it to “burn out”. Despite the brightness (about 15 lumens per watt) less than 5% of the filament produces light as energy. The rest is converted into thermal energy. The reason I say that a light bulb producing spontaneous emission is almost as complicated as a laser is because it cannot be explained by the classical electromagnetic theory. It is, by and large, a quantum process. This process involves exciting atoms within the filament form a ground state to a higher energy state. As the atoms become more and more excited they thy to conserve their energy by dropping back to as near the ground state as electromagnetically possible and emit photons( the light you see) and the process begins anew for that atom. As long as the material is in a vacuum and as long as a current passes though the medium(filament), then these atoms will remain in constant flux. While the process is a long one on the atomic scale, we tend to perceive it as instantaneous. The photons themselves, apart from the system, travel instantaneously at the speed of light. There is no acceleration because they were accelerated AT the speed of light to begin with. If you imagine the quantum process as someone pulling the plunger back on a pinball machine and holing it momentarily, then you can see the ball atop the plunger at rest. However as soon as the plunger is released, all of the stored energy in the spring is instantly released and the ball already moving as fast as it can move. So the short answer is when you flick on a light switch light is moving at ~186,000 miles a second instantly. The process to get the light to move took a little longer, even if you were not able to observe it.

It is mass which requires an application of momentum to increase its velocity relative to its context. A photon is massless. It is pure momentum and does not require ‘acceleration’ to be at its max velocity when it is emitted from an electron. The absorption and emission of momentum from matter is not well understood and we really have no clue to Gravity other than to describe it Contrary to some opinions, Gravity does not propagate at the speed of light because it would be required that matter be created fresh in order to generate such a field to measure. Gravitational waves travel at the speed of light but they are not Gravity per se but perturbations in a universal gravitational field composed of all of the mass in our Universe because the Gravitational field of any single particle of mass is infinite, albeit declining in intensity by the inverse square law with distance. The Gravitational asymptote never reaches zero. I believe that when our primitive instruments become more sensitive, we will find an entire spectrum of such Gravitational perturbations constantly washing past us in all directions.
